State Key Laboratory of Polymer Materials Engineering of China (Sichuan University) Polymer Research Institute of Sichuan University Chengdu 610065 China Graphical abstract CZAm prepared by the novel method exhibits advanced reducibility, more bulk and surface defects sites, which promotes the interaction between CZAm and Pd species. Then the Pd/CZAm could keep a better three-way activity even being thermally aged. A highly active Pd/CeO2-ZrO2-Al2O3(Pd/CZAm) catalyst was successfully fabricated by optimizing the reducibility of CZAm support through a novel precipitation method. Pd/CZAm-a (aged catalyst) could maintain a superior activity, the T90 (temperature for 90% conversion) of CO, NO and HC has decreased by 36 °C, 30 °C and 54 °C comparing with Pd/CZAc-a (reference catalyst). As characterized, the better activity of Pd/CZAm is associated closely with the advanced reducibility of CZAm support. By controlling the individual precipitation process of CZ and Al2O3 via two different precipitants, the CZAm which displays more homogeneous CZ structure, abundant surface and bulk oxygen defects manifested by XRD, Raman, XPS and TEM-EDS results has been successfully prepared without any additives and excess treatment. Then stronger interaction between CZAm and supported Pd species has been manifested by XPS, H2-TPR and CO-IR results, which prevents the sintering and decomposition of PdO species during aging process. Consequently, Pd/CZAm-a could maintain the better dispersion of Pd species and more oxidized PdO with respect to Pd/CZAc-a. Keywords Pd/CeO2-ZrO2-Al2O3 Novel precipitation method Low-temperature reducibility Surface defect sites Metal-support interaction 1 Introduction Three-way catalysts (TWCs), working as one of the most effective solutions to simultaneously eliminate carbon monoxide (CO), hydrocarbons (HC) and nitrogen oxides (NOx), have been widely used in gasoline fueled vehicles [1,2]. For a typical TWC, there contains precious metals (Rh, Pt and Pd), support materials and promoters. Among various TWCs, Pd-only TWCs have received considerable attention due to their better resistance to thermal sintering and higher activity for removing HC and CO than other precious metals. In these Pd-only TWCs, Al2O3 and CeO2-ZrO2 are usually used as support due to their higher specific surface area and unique redox property, respectively [3–5]. To further satisfy the requirements of surface area and thermal stability for the TWCs, CeO2-ZrO2-Al2O3(CZA) material, motivated by “diffusion barrier” effect, has been practically applied in TWCs as support [6,7]. To meet the increasingly stringent emission control requirements, it is a key technology to further enhance the lower-temperature reducibility of CZA material. Generally, the abundant defect sites of CZA support with better reducibility facilitates to make the supported PdO species more stable due to the easier diffusion and transferring of oxygen, which is effective in eliminating CO and HC [8,9]. Meanwhile, the activated oxygen released from CZA with better low-temperature reducibility could also be effective in eliminating HC [10]. In addition, the increased oxygen vacancies around Pd-CZ interfaces are beneficial for the activation and dissociation of NOx [11]. As reported [12–14], origin of the reducibility of CZ-based material is the phase transformation between Ce3+(Ce2O3) and Ce4+(CeO2) by lattice oxygen release and storage. Generally, the CZ solid solution with homogeneous distribution of Ce and Zr presents better low-temperature reducibility. Considering the fact that Al2O3 could not insert into CeO2 lattice [15] and be reduced at ordinary conditions, it is technologically important to achieve the regular distribution of Ce and Zr for synthesizing CZA with better low-temperature reducibility. Morikawa et al. significantly improved the reducibility of CZA by a reductive treatment due to the regular distribution of Ce and Zr ions in CeZrO4 [10]. Afterwards, Zhang et al. also prepared a CZA with advanced low-temperature reducibility after a redox treatment, in which the pyrochlore-like superstructure (Ce2Zr2O8) formed [16]. However, the formation of CeAlO3 is inevitable by the solid reaction between CeO2 and Al2O3 under high-temperature reductive treatment, which would disturb the reducibility [17]. Besides, a lower specific surface area of these CZA materials treated under reductive atmosphere is also detected. In addition, optimizing the preparation methods could also improve the reducibility of CZA without sacrificing its textural property. Deng et al. [18] and Guo et al. [19] reported that hydrothermal treatment could incorporate Zr4+ into CeO2 lattice to improve the reducibility of CZ. Meanwhile, Papavasiliou et al. also obtained CZ with advanced reducibility by using (NH4)2Ce(NO3)6 as precursor due to the closer solubility product of Ce(OH)4 and Zr(OH)4, and the electrostatic interaction between Ce(NO3)6 2− and ZrO2+ [20,21]. However, the excess hydrothermal treatment and the expensive cost of (NH4)2Ce(NO3)6 limits their widespread application. Afterwards, Sasol Germany GmbH [22] and Johnson Matthey public limited company [23] prepared CZA materials with superior reducibility by depositing the CZ precursors onto the pseudoboehmite, while excess organic dispersants are generally indispensable to ensure the homogeneous distribution of components. Then, the sequential precipitation method, in which CZ and Al2O3 are precipitated step by step, has been gradually reported to improve the element homogeneity [21,24]. However, in these works, the precipitation parameters for CZ and Al2O3 are generally fixed identical ignoring their different properties, as a result, the improvement in reducibility is limited. In our previous work, we have concluded that CZ and Al2O3 match different precipitants in precipitation reactions for their distinct contributions. Specifically, the CZA precipitated by NH3•H2O exhibits superior reducibility due to the quick precipitation of Ce and Zr, however, the CZA precipitated by (NH4)2•CO3 displays a much higher specific surface area [25]. Considering that the reducibility and surface area of CZA are mainly contributed by CZ and Al2O3, respectively, it is rational to assume that an ideal CZA could be achieved by controlling the nucleation process of CZ and Al2O3 separately via the two different precipitants without any additives and excess treatment. Then in this work, a novel, simple and economical precipitation method, in which NH3•H2O and (NH4)2•CO3 buffer solution are used separately to interact with CZ and Al2O3, will be introduced to synthesize a CZA with the advantages of lower-temperature reducibility and specific surface area, and then the relationship between the reducibility of CZA and the properties of its supported Pd catalysts will be discussed. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalysts preparation CeO2-ZrO2-Al2O3(CZA) materials, in which the ratio of CeO2-ZrO2/Al2O3 = 3/7 (wt%/wt%) and nCe:nZr = 1/1(mol/mol), were prepared by two different methods in the reactor displayed in Scheme 1 , where CZAm was prepared by the novel method, in which precipitant I and precipitant II in Scheme 1 are NH3•H2O (3 mol/L) and (NH4)2CO3 buffer solution (3 mol/L), respectively. For CZAc, both precipitant I and precipitant II are (NH4)2CO3 buffer solution (3 mol/L). In addition, the other experimental procedures are the same and the details are as follows. Firstly, CZ salt solution (100 mL) was achieved by dissolving Ce(NO3)3•6H2O (4.33 g) and ZrOCO3 (3.73 g) using dis-tilled water and concentrated nitric acid (68 wt%, 0.86 mL), respectively. Then Al(NO3)3•9H2O (51.45 g) was dissolved by distilled water to obtain a solution donated as Al (100 mL). Then CZ and Al were precipitated separately in the precipitation reactor I and precipitation reactor II, respectively, then mixed in the mixing reactor. The pH was maintained at around 8.8–9.0 in the precipitation process. After being aged at 90 °C for 6 h, the precipitates were filtered and dried. Finally, the precipitation powders were calcined at 900 °C for 3 h to get the fresh materials marked as CZAc-f and CZAm-f, respectively. Next, the supports CZAc-f and CZAm-f were impregnated with aqueous solution of Pd(NO3)2 (0.2 g/mL) to get the fresh Pd/CZAc-f and Pd/CZAm-f catalysts and the loading of Pd was 1.0 wt%. After being dried and thermally treated at 550 °C for 3 h, the catalysts were mixed with de-ionized water to produce slurries with 40 wt% solid content, which were coated to cylindrical cordierite monoliths (Corning, USA, 400 cells/in.2, 2.5 cm3). The excess of slurry was removed by blowing air through the channels, and the desirable washcoat loading was 140 g·L−1. Afterwards, the catalysts were calcined at 900 °C for 5 h to get the aged catalysts. For comparison, the fresh CZA supports were also treated at 900 °C for another 5 h to get the aged counterparts. 2.2 Catalytic activity measurements The activity of catalysts was evaluated in a fixed-bed reactor with a gas hourly space velocity of 50,000 h−1. The simulated exhaust gases include O2 (4390 ppm), NO (1100 ppm), CO (5100 ppm), H2 (1700 ppm), C3H8 (110 ppm), C3H6 (220 ppm), CO2 (10.5%), H2O (10.0%) and N2 (as balance gas). After being activated at 550 °C for 1 h under the simulated exhaust, the catalyst was cooled down to room temperature. After that, the conversions of all the target pollutants with temperature were recorded by a Thermo Scientific AntarisIGS Gas Analyzer. 2.3 Characterization techniques Transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) was characterized on ZEISS Libra 200 FE transmission electron microscope with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. FTIR spectra of CO adsorption (CO-IR) were acquired by Nicolet 6700 Fourier transform infrared spectrometer equipped with MCT detector. After being pretreated in H2/N2 flow at 450 °C for 1 h and being cooled down to room temperature, the CO was switched and held for 45 min. Then after being purging with N2, the CO adsorption spectra were obtained. CO transient pulse experiment was also used to characterize the dispersion of Pd species. Firstly, the samples (200 mg) were pretreated under H2 flow at 450 °C for 40 min to reduce PdO into metal Pd. Then the He flow was introduced to remove the residual hydrogen on the catalyst surface and to simultaneously cool the sample to room temperature. Finally, a certain amount of CO (controlled by six-way valve) was pulsed every 2 min into the sample until the height of adsorption peak keeps steady (the excess CO was detected by a gas chromatography). Then the dispersion of Pd was calculated by Eq. (1), assuming that 1 molecule of CO adsorbed per surface Pd atom. Where D refers to the dispersion of Pd species (%); Vm: the volume of adsorbed CO (mL, STP); M: mole mass of Pd (g/mol); m: the mass of the catalyst sample (g); wt (%): weight fraction of noble metal in the catalyst (%). In addition, the turnover frequency (TOF) values are calculated based on the results of CO chemisorption by Eqs. (2)–(3). And F is the inlet reactant molar flow rate (mol/g/s), X is the fractional conversion of reactant at a certain temperature (< 25%), υ is the stoichiometric coefficient of reactant, and W is the weight of the catalyst (g). Mpd represents the atomic weight of metal Pd (g/mol), Xpd is the metal weight percent, and D is the metal dispersion (%). (1) D = V m M 22414 m w t * 100 % (2) Rate=FX/υW (3) TOF=RMpd/DXpd N2 adsorption–desorption of the sample was characterized by Autosorb SI Quantachrome automated surface area & pore size analyzer. After being degassed at 300 °C for 1 h, the sample was cooled to −196 °C to measure the adsorption of N2. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on a XSAM-800 electron spectrometer (Kratos, Britain). Measurements were operated at 15 kV and 20 mA with Mg Kα (1253.6 eV) X-ray source, and the binding energy of all elements was calibrated by C 1s binding energy (284.6 eV). H2-Temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was carried out on a TP-5076 temperature-programmed adsorption instrument. 100 mg sample was pretreated in N2 flow at 550 °C for 1 h to clean the surface. After that, the system was cooled to ambient temperature and the mixed gases 5% H2/N2 were held into the system. Then the reduction behaviors of the samples were monitored by thermal conductivity detector (TCD) from room temperature to 900 °C with 10 °C/min. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) were characterized on a Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer (Rigaku, Japan), which was operated at 40 kV and 25 mA during measurements. In the process, samples were scanned by Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) in 10° < 2θ < 90° with a step rate of 0.02°/s. Raman spectra were collected using a Renishaw in Viareflex Raman spectrometer with 532 nm excitation wavelength, and the frequency collected is in the range of 100–1000 cm−1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The activity of Pd-only three-way catalysts Conversion profiles of pollutants over Pd/CZA catalysts are displayed in Fig. 1 . As shown in Fig. 1(a–c), fresh Pd/CZA catalysts exhibit slight differences in these target pollutants conversions, however, obvious distinct is detected for the aged catalysts. Specifically, Pd/CZAm-a keeps a superior activity and the T90 of CO, NO and HC decreases by 36 °C, 30 °C and 54 °C compared to Pd/CZAc-a (Fig. 1d–f). Moreover, as presented in Table 1 , Pd/CZAm also displays a lowerΔT90, which only decrease by about 30 °C for all the target pollutants between the fresh and aged catalysts. However, much higher ΔT90 for Pd/CZAc is observed, and theΔT90 for HC is even as high as about 80 °C. It manifests that a highly active and thermally stabled Pd/CZAm catalyst has been achieved by the novel method in this work. 3.2 The property of catalysts Activity of Pd-only three-way catalysts usually correlates closely with the chemistry state of Pd species, then further characterizations were carried out to explain the differences between the two catalysts. 3.2.1 TEM, CO-IR and BET results TEM was performed to investigate the size distribution of Pd particles, and the Pd particles are donated by red arrow in Fig. 2 . In Fig. 2, particle size of Pd species in fresh catalysts is concentrated at 1–4 nm. However, more dense particles have been detected in aged catalysts due to the sintering and agglomeration. For Pd/CZAm-a, Pd particles are more concentrated in the range of 2–4 nm, and the particles above 10 nm is absent. Conversely, the Pd particle size distribution in Pd/CZAc-a is wider and the particles larger than 10 nm are also observed. It may indicate the poor Pd dispersion of Pd/CZAc-a due to the more large Pd particles. Then CO-IR and CO chemisorption were carried out to further investigate the difference of Pd dispersion between the two catalysts. Obviously in Fig. 3 , all Pd/CZA exhibit three types of adsorption peaks at 2072 cm−1, 1962 cm−1 and 1918 cm−1. High frequency (HF) peak at 2072 cm−1 is ascribed to on-top(linearly) CO-Pd, while those at 1962 cm-1 and 1918 cm−1 (low frequencies/LF) correspond to bridge-bonded CO-Pd2 and 3-fold hollow CO-Pd3 [2,26,27]. Higher ratio between the area of HF and LF can be referred to smaller Pd particles [3]. For fresh catalysts, a closer HF/LF ratio between the two catalysts is detected, indicating the similar Pd particle size. However, Pd/CZAm-a exhibits a much higher HF/LF ratio (0.3534) and higher Pd dispersion than Pd/CZAc-a (0.2585) even though the band intensity of both aged catalysts decreases sharply due to the reduce of CO adsorption sites by Pd particles aggregation and/or encapsulation. Meanwhile, CO chemisorption results also manifest the better Pd dispersion of Pd/CZAm-a, since the order of Pd dispersion follows as: Pd/CZAm-a (10.54%) > Pd/CZAc-a (8.69%) (Table 2 ). Meanwhile, the blue shift of CO adsorption band over Pd/CZAc-a (2077 cm-1 and 1966 cm−1) with respect to Pd/CZAm-a (2070 cm−1 and 1962 cm−1) also indicates the aggregation of Pd particles in Pd/CZAc-a due to the decrease of π back-donation from Pd particles to CO molecule [28]. In addition, the TOF values of the aged catalysts for CO, C3H6, C3H8 and NO were also calculated and the results are displayed in Table 2. Obviously in Table 2, Pd/CZAm-a displays higher TOF values for both CO and HC oxidation with respect to Pd/CZAc-a, which indicates the better intrinsic properties of Pd species in Pd/CZAm-a. As generally accepted, support with large specific surface area is beneficial to disperse active species. However, as presented in Table 3 , Pd/CZAc and Pd/CZAm exhibit almost the same specific surface area, pore volume and even ΔSBET. It indicates that the specific surface area plays a little role in determining the dispersion of Pd species. 3.2.2 XPS results Except for the dispersion, chemical state of Pd species also correlates with the activity, then the XPS was characterized. Fig. 4 depicts the Pd 3d spectra, which could be deconvoluted into two peaks with Pd2+ and Pd0 [29,30]. In Fig. 4(a), only the peak referring to Pd2+ is detected for fresh Pd/CZA, indicating that surface Pd species are mainly in oxidized state. Moreover, the binding energy of Pd2+ 5/2 for Pd/CZAm-f (337.03 eV) is higher than that of Pd/CZAc-f (336.81 eV). On the one hand, it implies stronger metal-support interaction between CZAm-f and Pd species [31]. On the other hand, it may be related to the smaller particle size of Pd species in Pd/CZAm-f since the binding energy of Pd 3d5/2 increases with decreasing the particle size of PdO as reported by Kobayshi et al [32]. Considering the similar Pd particle size in fresh catalysts (section 3.2.1), it could ascribe the higher binding energy value of Pd2+ 5/2 in Pd/CZAm-f to stronger metal-support interaction between CZAm and Pd species. In addition, obvious differences between Pd 3d spectra of aged catalysts can be detected in Fig. 4(b) and Table 4 . Curve fitting analyses of Pd/CZA-a reveal that metallic Pd0 has formed due to the decomposition of PdO species in aging process. However, Pd/CZAm-a also keeps the higher Pd2+ fraction (66.80%) and surface Pd content (0.12%) than Pd/CZAc-a (49.28%, 0.07%). That is to say, Pd/CZAm exhibits superior thermal stability in terms of keeping highly dispersed PdO species. Besides, special attention should be paid to the fraction of Ce3+ and Oβ for CeO2-based systems, since it generally associates with the oxygen vacancies. The peak Ce 3d spectra, shown in Fig. 5 , could be fitted into eight peaks, in which the doublet (u’, v’) is characteristic of Ce3+ species and the others are assigned to Ce4+ [33,34]. The fraction of Ce3+ is calculated by the area ratio of peak u’, v’ to the area sum of Ce 3d. Similarly, as displayed in Fig. 6 , the O 1s spectra could be fitted into two peaks at around 529.0 eV and 530.8 eV, which are assigned to lattice oxygen(Oα) and surface adsorbed oxygen, OH groups and oxygen vacancies(Oβ) [39]. As displayed in Table 4, Pd/CZAm exhibits larger value of Ce3+ and Oβ fractions than Pd/CZAc. As disclosed by massive literatures, the formation of Ce3+ is related with oxygen defects and the increased oxygen vacancies in proximity of Pd-CZ interface would facilitate the dissociation of N–O bond, resulting in better NO conversion [11,35]. Meanwhile, Oβ species are reported to be more active due to their higher mobility with respect to Oα, which may also play a positive role in three-way catalytic reactions [29,36]. In addition, surface elemental distribution of pure CZA supports was also investigated by XPS. Obviously, the surface Ce/Zr ratio in CZAm is close to the theoretical value (nCe/nZr = 1/1), proving the formation of a more homogenous CZ solid solution [37,38]. Consequently, CZAm exhibits a higher Ce3+ and Oβ fraction compared with CZAc. When Pd species are loaded on CZA, the Ce/Zr ratio, Ce3+ combining with Oβ fraction are observed to decrease obviously, referring that Pd species are prone to absorb on surface defect sites [18,39]. Then the CZAm with abundant surface defect sites facilitates to make supported PdO species more stable due to the easier diffusion and transfer of oxygen [8,9]. To further illustrate the support-metal interactions, Table 5 exhibits the binding energy of all elements in CZA and catalysts. More obvious shifts (> 0.3 eV) of Ce 3d and O 1s spectra to lower binding energy are observed in Pd/CZAm-f with respect to CZAm-f, which proves the stronger support-metal interaction in Pd/CZAm-f. 3.2.3 H2-TPR results Redox property of CZA and Pd/CZA is also critical for its application, then H2-TPR was carried out. In Fig. 7 (a), CZAm-f exhibits a dominant broad peak with maxima at 595 °C and an obvious shoulder peak at 450 °C, while the maxima reduction peak of CZAc-f moves to 629 °C and the low temperature reduction (< 500 °C) is rather weak. Asymmetric reduction peak of CZ-based material could be fitted into the reduction at surface and in bulk, which usually occur at about 500 °C and 800 °C, respectively [40–42]. Namely, there are much more active reducible surface species in CZAm than that in CZAc. Besides, CZAm-f also displays much higher H2 consumption (460.11 μmol/g), which is 1.48 times higher than that of CZAc-f (311.28 μmol/g) (Fig.7c). Meanwhile, comparing the profiles of aged supports with fresh ones (Fig. 7a–b), thermal aging induces significant changes of reduction behaviors. The peak intensities of CZA-a decline sharply compared to those of CZA-f, which is consistent with the decreased H2 consumption displayed in Fig.7(c). While CZAm-a keeps better reducibility with lower reduction temperature and higher H2 consumption than CZAc-a does. Fig. 8 depicts H2-TPR profiles of Pd-only catalysts, in which three peaks donated as α, β and γ could be detected. Negative peak (α) at 30 °C is ascribed to the decomposition of palladium hydride; Peak β is ascribed to the reduction of stable PdO species interacted with support and the reduction of Ce4+ located at interface of palladium species [5,38]; Peak γ is referred to the reduction of Ce4+ having weak interaction with PdOx species [18]. Obviously, reduction of catalysts could be finished at rather lower temperature (< 400 °C) by comparison with CZA supports (Fig. 7), indicating that supported Pd species benefit the back-spillover of oxygen species from support to PdO surface [43]. In Fig. 8(a) and Table 6 , a much stronger peak γ with larger H2 consumption of 50.5 μmol/g is observed in Pd/CZAc-f than Pd/CZAm-f (14.8 μmol/g), which indicates that CZAc-f is weakly interacted with Pd species. Besides, as discussed in XPS and CO-IR results, Pd species supported on CZAc-f and CZAm-f are all highly dispersed and are mainly exhibited in oxidized state. Consequently, it is reasonable that the total H2 consumption of the catalysts is higher than that of pure CZA. However, the detected H2 consumption of fresh catalysts orders as: Pd/CZAc-f (120.4 μmol/g) > Pd/CZAm-f (61.4 μmol/g). On the one hand, total H2 consumption of both Pd/CZAc-f and Pd/CZAm-f is lower than their pure CZA supports. On the other hand, the sequence of H2 consumption of catalysts is opposite with CZAc-f (311.3 μmol/g) < CZAm-f (460.1 μmol/g). Thus, the highly dispersed PdO species and partly CZA have been reduced below the test temperature (< 15 °C) [8]. Considering the detected lower H2 consumption of Pd/CZAm-f, it could be inferred that CZAm-f and PdO species interact intimately and consequently more reducible species including CZAm-f and PdO species are easily reduced below test temperature. After being aged, things become complicated due to the transform of Pd chemical state and dispersion, textural and reducibility of CZA. While it is also obvious that the intensity of peak α increases sharply especially for Pd/CZAc-a, which further infers its lower palladium dispersion since larger palladium particles are in favor of the formation and decomposition of PdHx [5]. As we all known, three-way catalytic reaction is a typical solid-gas heterogeneous reaction. And there generally include three steps for heterogenous catalytic reactions: (1) reactants adsorbed on the active sites over the catalysts; (2) reaction and (3) product desorption. For CO oxidation reaction, CO would adsorb on Pd surface, after which the adsorbed CO reacts with the adsorbed O to produce CO2 [44]. As massive literatures reported, the oxidation of CO on Pd surface is a structure-insensitive reaction proceeding through a Langmuir–Hinshelwood kinetic [8,28]. Consequently, the higher dispersion of Pd species could promote CO adsorption, meanwhile, more Pd-CZ interface could be created with the smaller Pd particles. In addition, the adsorbed O may come from (i) gaseous oxygen species, which could be activated on surface oxygen vacancies; (ii) oxygen species originating from the support and PdOx particles [45]. Then the abundant oxygen vacancies play an important role in oxygen migration since the diffusion of O2− is driven by the oxygen concentration gradient from bulk to the surface [46]. As for CxHy oxidation, similar process would happen like CO oxidation that CxHy would also firstly be adsorbed on the Pd sites, followed by being oxidized by the O activated by the surface oxygen vacancies [47]. For NO reduction, NO would also firstly adsorb on Pd surface, which is followed by the dissociation of adsorbed NO species on vacant sites. Further, the dissociative N atom may react with NO species or N atom to form N2O and N2, respectively [11,48]. As a result, the oxygen vacancies in Pd/CZ interface could also improve the NO conversion activity by promoting NO dissociation through partially capturing oxygen atom from NO molecules. Combined with the discussions above, the reasons for better activity for Pd/CZAm-a may be as follows: i. Pd/CZAm-a maintains higher Pd dispersion, thus keeps more active sites; ii. Pd/CZAm-a keeps more oxidized PdO species, which promotes HC and CO oxidation [3]; iii. Abundant oxygen defects in Pd-CZ interface of Pd/CZAm-a contribute to its excellent NO reduction performance for promoting the dissociation of NO [11]. iv. Pd/CZAm exhibits better reducibility than Pd/CZAc, indicating that oxygen species in Pd/CZAm are more active and available in practical operating conditions. 3.2.4 XRD and Raman results As discussed above, CZAm exhibits more surface defects sites, better reducibility and thus improves the thermal stability of the supported PdO species. Considering the similar textural property between CZAc and CZAm, it could be inferred that the structural property plays a decisive role in determining the reducibility of these CZA supports, then the XRD and Raman characterizations were performed. In Fig. 9 (a), main diffraction peaks of CZA are consistent with cubic CZ solid solution and γ-Al2O3. As amplified in Fig. 9(b), a higher 2θ value ascribed to cubic CZ is found in CZAm (29.14°) than that of CZAc (28.97°), which is closer to that of pure CZ (29.28, PDF 54-0017). Based on Vegard’s rule, shift of XRD peak is correlated with lattice contraction or expansion, thus higher peak angle of CZ solid solution in CZAm indicates the contraction of the host lattice [49]. As reported, Al2O3 could not incorporate into CeO2 lattice to form CZA solid solution [6,15,50], it could be inferred that the novel method facilitates the incorporation of Zr into the CeO2 lattice and improves the solid solubility of Ce and Zr in CZAm due to the smaller ionic radius of Zr4+(0.88 Å) than Ce4+(0.97 Å). Consistent with XRD results, an upshift of Raman peak at ca. 465 cm−1 ascribed to F2g vibration mode of cubic fluorite-type structure is also observed for CZAm (Fig. 9c). Then the concentration of oxygen vacancies in CZ solution solid was evaluated by the ratio of ID/IF2g, where ID and IF2g are the maximum intensity of the defect band centered at ∼630 cm−1 and the band of fluorite-type structure, respectively. The larger ratio indicates an increase in the concentration of oxygen defects sites [5,51,52]. Larger ID/IF2g value of CZAm-f (0.3138) than CZAc-f (0.1316) manifests that novel method is beneficial to increase the oxygen defects in ceria lattice. Then these generated oxygen vacancies contributed to the better reducibility of CZAm since it could make more mobile lattice oxygen available during redox process [2,20,21,24]. After being aged, sharper diffraction peaks are found in XRD and Raman profiles due to thermal sintering, therefore, deteriorated redox properties have been displayed in CZA (Fig. 7). While CZAm-a also keeps larger ID/IF2g (0.1821) ratio and thus more oxygen vacancies with respect to CZAc-a (0.0588), which is consistent with H2-TPR results that CZAm-a could maintain larger H2 consumption after being thermally aged (Fig. 7c). In addition, Raman spectra of Pd/CZA catalysts are also displayed in Fig. 10 . By comparing with the Raman spectra of pure CZA support (Fig. 9c), characteristic Raman peaks at 276 cm−1, 440 cm−1, 560 cm−1, 640 cm-1 and 712 cm−1 associated with well-developed PdOx species are observed. As presented in Fig. 10(a), the palladium species are highly dispersed on fresh CZA surface since only the rather weak peak at 640 cm−1 of PdO are observed. On contrary, significant peak sharpening is observed for the aged Pd/CZA catalysts, thus the F2g peaks of CZ were weakened by these palladium species at top surface of CZA support. Special attention should be paid to the sharp peak located at around 640 cm−1, which is ascribed to the B1 mode of PdO [52,53]. From the amplifying patterns displayed in Fig. 10(b), the intensity of the Raman band at 640 cm-1 in Pd/CZAm-a is higher than that in Pd/CZAc-a. As reported, the intensity of the Raman peak is generally associated with the crystal size and the amount of vibrant oxygen. As manifested by TEM and CO-IR results that the palladium particle size in Pd/CZAm-a is smaller than that in Pd/CZAc-a, then here the increase of intensity is due to the larger amount of vibrant oxygen, which suggests the existence of more PdO species in Pd/CZAm-a [52,54]. In addition, according to the reports, the Raman peak of PdO would shift to higher wavenumber if severe encapsulation of Pd particles induced by strong support-metal interaction (SMSI) have occurred [55]. However, from the amplifying patterns displayed in Fig. 10(b), the wavenumber between the two aged catalysts could be ignored. Then combined with the larger particle size of Pd after being thermally aged as manifested by CO-IR results, it could ascribe the decrease of surface Pd content on Pd/CZAm-a to the particle agglomeration rather than the strong SMSI effects [56]. 3.2.5 TEM-EDS results TEM-EDS was further used to characterize the microscopic element composition. As reported, one particle could be identified as Al2O3 if the content of Al in the spot is higher than average value, otherwise, the spot is regarded as CZ [6]. Then the spots recognized as CZ are donated in red and those referred to Al2O3 are in blue in Fig. 11 . Special attention should be paid to Ce/Zr ratio for CZ analysis spots. In Fig. 11, the Ce/Zr ratio in Pd/CZAc-a fluctuates from 0.05 to 0.59 (Fig. 10c). On contrary, Ce/Zr ratio in Pd/CZAm-a is closer to theoretical value of 1. It further manifests that a more homogeneous CZ solid solution has formed in CZAm, the results of which is also consistent with surface Ce/Zr ratio detected by XPS. 3.3 Discussion Combined with the discussion above, it could manifest the critical role of reducibility and defects sites of the CZA support in affecting the performance of its supported Pd-only catalysts. For CZAm prepared by the novel method, the CZ component exhibits a more homogenous distribution of Ce and Zr in CeO2 lattice due to the positive effects of NH3•H2O. On the one hand, the highly alkaline conditions could achieve the simultaneous precipitation of Ce3+ and Zr4+ ignoring their great difference in solubility product. On the other hand, the hydrogen bonds among Zr(OH)4, Ce(OH)3 and/or Ce(OH)4 benefits to improve the solid solubility of Ce and Zr in CeO2 lattice [57,58]. Then as illustrated in Fig. 12 , CZAm exhibits larger solid solubility of Ce and Zr, thus advanced reducibility and abundant bulk and surface defect sites with respect to CZAc. Then by H2-TPR, XPS and CO-IR results, a stronger interaction between Pd species and CZAm is detected since the Pd species selectively interact with the surface defects sites. And the abundant surface defect sites, the higher mobility of the oxygen species in CZAm make the supported PdO species more stable due to the easier diffusion and transfer of oxygen [8,9]. Therefore, Pd/CZAm-a could maintain the better dispersion of Pd species, more oxidized PdO species and more surface defects sites with respect to Pd/CZAc-a after thermal treatment. Consequently, Pd/CZAm-a could keep a superior activity for the T90 of CO, NO and HC decrease by 36 °C, 30 °C and 54 °C than Pd/CZAc-a, respectively. 4 Conclusions This work illuminates the importance of the support in improving the activity of supported Pd-only three-way catalyst. By controlling the precipitation process of CZ and Al2O3 via two different precipitants, respectively, a novel CZAm with advanced reducibility can be synthesized without any additives and excess treatment. Compared with CZAc prepared by traditional precipitating method, CZAm shows advanced reducibility and more surface defect sites. Then stronger interaction between Pd and CZAm is detected, therefore, Pd/CZAm-a could maintain the better dispersion of Pd species and more oxidized PdO species. Consequently, Pd/CZAm-a displays a better three-way catalytic activity for the T90 of CO, NO and HC decrease by 36 °C, 30 °C and 54 °C than Pd/CZAc-a. coredata.dc:description: A highly active Pd/CeO2-ZrO2-Al2O3(Pd/CZAm) catalyst was successfully fabricated by optimizing the reducibility of CZAm support through a novel precipitation method. Pd/CZAm-a (aged catalyst) could maintain a superior activity, the T90 (temperature for 90% conversion) of CO, NO and HC has decreased by 36 °C, 30 °C and 54 °C comparing with Pd/CZAc-a (reference catalyst). As characterized, the better activity of Pd/CZAm is associated closely with the advanced reducibility of CZAm support. By controlling the individual precipitation process of CZ and Al2O3 via two different precipitants, the CZAm which displays more homogeneous CZ structure, abundant surface and bulk oxygen defects manifested by XRD, Raman, XPS and TEM-EDS results has been successfully prepared without any additives and excess treatment. Then stronger interaction between CZAm and supported Pd species has been manifested by XPS, H2-TPR and CO-IR results, which prevents the sintering and decomposition of PdO species during aging process. Consequently, Pd/CZAm-a could maintain the better dispersion of Pd species and more oxidized PdO with respect to Pd/CZAc-a.
coredata.dc:title: Design and synthetize highly active Pd-only three-way catalyst by optimizing the reducibility of CeO2-ZrO2-Al2O3 support
